clinical_study.brief_title: A Predictive Model for Inadequate Bowel Preparation
clinical_study.official_title: A Predictive Model for Inadequate Bowel Preparation: Development and Validation With a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: We aimed to develop a predictive model of inadequate bowel preparation and to further validate it by a randomized controlled trial.

primary_outcome.description: The quality of bowel preparation is evaluated using BBPS.

secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of patients from whom at least one adenoma can be detected.
The proportion of patients from whom at least one polyp can be detected.
Including nausea, bloating, stomachache, vomiting, vertigo and belching and so on.

arm_group.description: In the tailored group, high-risk patients are instructed to drink the first 2 L of Polyethylene Glycol (PEG) at 19:00-21:00 hours on the day before colonoscopy at a rate of 250 ml every 15 min. On the day of the procedure, they take another 2 L PEG 4-6 h before colonoscopy. The low-risk patients were given a standard dose of 2 L PEG 4-6 h before colonoscopy.
In the control group, all the patients drink single dose of 2 l Polyethylene Glycol (PEG) 4-6 h before colonoscopy at a rate of 250 ml every 15 min.

intervention.description: In the Tailored group, high-risk people are given intensified bowel preparation regimens, low-risk people are given routine regimens. In the control group, all the patients are given routine regimens.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients aged 18-75 years undergoing colonoscopy
Exclusion Criteria:
- known or suspected bowel obstruction, stricture or perforation
- compromised swallowing reflex or mental status
- severe chronic renal failure(creatinine clearance < 30 ml/min)
- severe congestive heart failure (New York Heart Association class III or IV)
- uncontrolled hypertension (systolic blood pressure > 170 mm Hg, diastolic blood pressure > 100 mm Hg)
- dehydration
- disturbance of electrolytes
- pregnancy or lactation
- hemodynamically unstable
- unable to give informed consent
